intro: Oxytropis hallii, commonly known as Hall's milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its upright growth habit and trifoliate leaves. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that range in color from white to purple, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in sagebrush steppe ecosystems. Oxytropis hallii is adapted to arid conditions and plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native range.
